replies.context: ...zackly, I waded through the whole story and never heard a Fahrenhiet, Celsius or even a Kelvin.....

It's Associated Press: They don't think we're smart enough to get beyond the 'shiny stuff,' and we shouldn't trust them to 'splain it. Maybe they had solar powered air conditioning.

from the "back" side of the spacecraft that faces deep space (very cold)...
üëç
The dark side of Mercury is just 23¬∞ above absolute zero.
Which side is dark? Is it the other side?

There‚Äôs a difference between heat and temperature. High temperatures don‚Äôt always mean high heat. The probe is protected by a heat shield that is 11‚Äô around and 4‚Äù thick. The probe only gets heated to around 2,500¬∞ F. The heat shield can withstand this.

Yes, there is a difference between heat and temperature.  Heat is thermal energy and temperature is a measure of how much thermal energy there is in an object.  The space craft survives because it can radiate its thermal energy away into all of space (with a radiation temperature a few degrees above absolute zero) to compensate for radiant energy input from the sun.

context: This is a hot topic for scientist!!

If the sun expands , say 100 feet out. how much more sunlight and heat will be released. Can those here on earth measure this? I just asking because I've read where Venus, Mars, and all the planets are warming ever so slightly. maybe part of the reason for global warming .

replies.context: The effect wouldn't be noticeable, considering the fact that the sun does expand and contract on a regular basis... far further than 100 feet out.

but could it impact the Earths weather, Hotter/colder, 100 feet may not be much, but the size could be, 
thank you, for the reply, enjoyed it.
Solar irradiance could yes, but the expansion and contraction of the sun wouldn't really affect that.

Again.. read what I said.  The sun's atmosphere expands and contracts by a HUGE margin (relatively speaking) between 7-10 miles.  For a star, that's basically nothing and is still considered in equilibrium It's practically unnoticeable.  For us on earth, literally nothing changes.  When the equilibrium is finally broken, however, the sun will start expanding by thousands of miles.  THEN you'll start noticing negative impact on the earth. Heck during our trip around the sun at our closest point we're 91 million miles away and at our furthest we're 94.5 million miles away.  Even by that large of a change (3.5 million miles) it has almost no real impact on us.  The only thing that is going to matter is when the sun starts burning helium and increases in temperature.

replies.context:
Weather is based on rapidly changing short term conditions.

Climate is based on long term conditions measured over decades.

I can't tell you if it will rain in July in Arizona.

I can tell you that the month of July will be hot and dry in Arizona.

Actually, July is one of our wettest months in AZ.  It is the start of our annual monsoon.  Yes, it's still very hot, but it is also our wettest season.  That said, no climate model since the 1980's has accurately predicted the climate into the future.  They have all been amazingly inaccurate.  There is no grant money available from federal granting agencies for research into WHY these models fail so miserably.  All the money is in climate change alarmism.  That is not how science is supposed to work.  It's as though all grant money for geology is going to fund the Flat Earth Society.

Fascinating.

The average precipitation for AZ in July is less than 1 inch, so while that may be 'above average', it doesn't change the fact that AZ is dry in July. It ranks 43rd overall for summer precipitation.

So yes, it is hot and dry in AZ in July.

And you just get more wrong from there :D

Yes, climate models have been highly accurate for decades now as the globe warmed precisely as anyone who understands the physics knows it will when CO2 levels rise.

"All the money is in climate change alarmism."

The majority of the money is funding science denialism, the only reason funding was increased for real science is to counter the anti-science nonsense. You are right, that is not how science is supposed to work. It is what happens when politics and financial interests try to influence the science.
